AMERICAN CHAMBER MUSIC
The advancement of chamber music performance in America during the past
tew years has been accompanied by an enormous increase in the number -— and
quality — of chamber music works composed by Americans. During the nineteenth
century a composition for a small instrumental combination from the pen of an
American composer was a rarity, though there was no shortage of symphonies,
operas, piano pieces, and many other forms of music. Today this genre is the
principal means of expression for many of our most gifted composers.
The years since World War II have been years not only of great development
of American chamber music, but of the universal recognition of that music, and of
its dissemination to many corners of the world. This phenomenon, which continues
undiminished, is due in considerable degree to the influx, and subsequent assimilation
into our culture, of many of the world's greatest composers during the I930's.
The summer series of chamber music concerts at the Museum presents a varied
and typical cross-section of the chamber music being created today by Americans,
native and transplanted. Some of these works will grow in stature with the years,
others will be forgotten. At the concerts, players and listeners alike will be contribut¬
ing to that historical process—and, we are sure, finding much pleasure in so doing.
—Robert Turner
